epd_metadata.epd_owner_address: Level 40, Northpoint Tower, 100 Miller St, North Sydney NSW 2060, Australia
epd_metadata.epd_produced_by_address: Level 3, Greenhouse, 180 George Street, Sydney NSW 2000 Australia
epd_metadata.accreditation_body_address: Suite 2600, 101 Marietta St NW, Atlanta, Georgia 30303, USA
epd_metadata.product_group_classification: UN CPC 375 (Articles of concrete, cement and plaster)

product_description.dangerous_goods_classification: Non-Dangerous Goods according to the Australian Code for the Transport of Dangerous Goods by Road and Rail
product_description.svhc_content: None of the products contain one or more substances that are listed in the “Candidate List of Substances of Very High Concern for authorisation”.
product_description.packaging: Delivered in bulk with no packaging

concrete_classes.description: Designed for everyday applications such as residential and commercial foundations, driveways and footpaths.

Typically supplied to major construction projects from high rise buildings, dams and spillways, roads, bridges to public works infrastructure etc. May include high-strength/high-performance, high durability, marine application, post-tensioned, high-pumpability, super workable, piling concrete, architectural off-form finishes and other decorative applications.

lca_information.scope: Cradle to gate (modules A1-A3) with options, modules A4-A5, modules C1-C4 and module D
lca_information.time_representativeness: Plant data: 2022 calendar year; Mix data: 2025 calendar year
databases_and_software: Product specific EPDs for cements, admixtures, pigments and fibres
Australian National Life Cycle Inventory Database (AusLCI v1.42) (2023)
lca_information.allocation: Intermediate flows allocated physically based on weight (quarries) or based on m3 of concrete (batching plant). Economic allocation used when physical allocation not possible. Fly ash and silica fumes are waste products and burden-free. Ground granulated blast furnace slag allocated economically.
lca_information.cut_off_criteria: Environmental impact from infrastructure, construction, production equipment, and tools not directly consumed in production are not accounted for. Personnel-related impacts are also excluded. No energy or mass flows, except packaging of materials, were excluded.

data_quality.assessment: Data quality was assessed in terms of geographic and temporal representativeness. All data sources were scored good or very good. Background data sources updated within 10 years as required under PCR 2019:14.

table.input: Cement Supplier data and EPD factors

lca_information.upstream_processes: Extraction, transport and manufacturing of raw materials. Generation of electricity from primary and secondary energy resources, including extraction, refining and transport for Modules A1 and A3.
lca_information.core_processes: External transportation of materials to the core processes and internal transport. Manufacturing of concrete (excluding mixing, which occurs in the mixing truck and is considered part of the A4 module). Treatment of waste and wastewater generated from the manufacturing processes.
lca_information.downstream_processes: Distribution of concrete mixes. Installation of the ready-mix concrete on the site. Wastage of construction products (accounted for in module A5). Transport of equipment and use of materials for deconstruction at end of life. Transport and treatment of waste generated at end of life.
lca_information.other_environmental_information: Module D indicates the environmental benefits from reuse, recovery, and recycling of deconstructed concrete.

deconstruction.process: Physical process of drilling and removing the concrete. Hydraulic excavator is assumed as the operating tool for deconstruction.

end_of_life.notes: 80% of the product is reprocessed/recycled as Module C3 (based on the 2022 National Waste Report). The remaining waste concrete undergoes inert waste landfill as Module C4.

carbon_emission_context.context: Currently, the building environment accounts for 39% of global CO2 emissions, with construction materials comprising 11% (World Green Building Council). By 2030, the embodied carbon of all construction materials needs to be at least 40% lower. By 2050, all new construction materials need to be net zero.

carbonation.description: Carbonation is a natural process whereby concrete absorbs CO2 from the atmosphere through a chemical reaction between the CO2 in the ambient air and hydration products within the concrete. This process can offset some of the CO2 emitted during cement manufacturing.
carbonation.consideration_in_epd: CO2 absorption (carbonation) has not been considered in this EPD and is not reflected in the EPD results tables.

recycled_materials_handling.allocation_approach: Co-products are considered as co-products of their production process and the impacts for their production process are allocated according to PCR 2019:14. Default background data from LCA databases was used.
recycled_materials_handling.fly_ash: AusLCI process treats as waste material and only includes transport impacts.
recycled_materials_handling.ground_granulated_blast_furnace_slag: AusLCI process allocated based on economic value.
recycled_materials_handling.silica_fume: Ecoinvent process treats as waste material and only includes transport impacts.
recycled_materials_handling.secondary_data_allocation: AusLCI LCA database allocation approach adopted as default for secondary data and processes.
recycled_materials_handling.recycling_and_recovery_rate: 80% of waste concrete is recycled at end of life (National Waste Report rate, DCCEEW, 2023).

references: Australasian EPD Programme. (2017). Guidance on the use of INA in EPDs.
Australasian EPD Programme. (2018). Guidance on the use of background LCI data.
Australasian EPD Programme. (2024). Instructions of the Australasian EPD Programme V4.2.
Australian Life Cycle Inventory Database Initiative (AusLCI). (2023). Guidelines for Data Development for an Australian Life Cycle Inventory Database, Data Standard.
Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water. (2023). National Waste Report 2022.
EPD International. (2024). General Programme Instructions (GPI) for the International EPD System V£.0.
EPD International. (2024). Product Category Rules for Construction Products and Construction Services, PCR2019:14 V1.3.4.
Green Building Council of Australia. (2022). An upfront conversation about upfront carbon.
Man Yu, Thomes Wiedmann, Robert Crawford, Catriona Tait, ‘The Carbon Footprint of Australia's Construction Sector’, Procedia Engineering, Volume 180, 2017.
World Green Building Council. (2019). Bringing embodied carbon upfront.
